awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT:  A reliable, fast and low-cost field test for hemp
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is to develop a reliable chemical field test that can easily and quickly differentiate between hemp and marijuana plants in the field. A miniaturized testing platform results in improved sensitivity and effectiveness.  This technology addresses a need to differentiate plants quickly and effectively for use by law enforcement, regulatory bodies, and also by the hemp growing industry. This PFI-TT project will accelerate the commercialization of a viable solution that will compete favorably with an existing technology and incorporate engineering expertise to address the scaling challenges to commercialize the rapid test kit.

The proposed project seeks to use a polymer-coated fiberglass substrate and a robust chemical reaction to provide miniaturized reaction results. The major technical challenge in the commercialization of the rapid test kit is the development of a prototype that can be industrially scalable for various market segments. In order to address the technical challenges, the team will validate the prototype kit with industry partners and standardize a versatile platform that is commercially viable and that can address various market segments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This project addresses the urgent need to differentiate hemp from marijuana with a fast and easy to use analytical method in the field. Hemp is defined as Cannabis sativa and any part or derivative of the plant including seeds, that has a tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) concentration below 0.3 % (w/w).  The 2018 Farm Bill permits the cultivation and legal trade of Industrial Hemp in the U.S. while marijuana (Cannabis plants containing > 0.3% THC ) remains illegal at the federal level and is either strictly regulated or illegal in all states. A novel field-testing technology combining new chemistry (Fast-Blue BB (FBBB) reagent) with proprietary materials developed in the Almirall research group facilitates the rapid, simple, inexpensive and reliable presumptive differentiation between cannabinoids in cannabis plant samples. The Almirall research group has characterized the product chromophores between FBBB and the cannabinoids showing that 50 ng of THC can be detected with FBBB reaction in a proprietary microextraction substrate and differentiate low THC/high CBD plants (hemp) from high THC/low CBD plants (marijuana). One aim of this effort is to develop a prototype field test for the rapid differentiation between hemp and marijuana in the field to assist both law enforcement efforts as well as the rapidly growing and regulated hemp grower industry. The project aims to demonstrate and validate a quantitative test for the FBBB + THC reaction producing clear color differences above and below the 0.3 % THC legal threshold, with assistance from industry partners. A second project aim was to develop a field portable test for THC in oral fluid based on the novel chemistry. A postdoctoral fellow and PhD student in the Almirall group works closely with a local biomedical engineering firm (ERG) to develop and evaluate a prototype field test kit. The market demand for rapid, easy to use and reliable field test kits for this application is apparent in two different market sectors.

 


Last Modified: 02/03/2025
Modified by: Yong Cai
